description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people responsible for the submitted dataset
A list (concatenated and separated) of the globally unique identifier for the people responsible for the submitted dataset
A contact person and their contact (i.e., email address) for data enquiry
An institution having custody of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
An identifier for the institution having custody of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized
A brief, concise project identifier with no spaces or special characters, ensuring machine readability. This ID will be used in data file names as 'project_id'.
The variable(s) examined in the study, including those of direct interests to address study aims and covariates.
example: benthic habitat types | diurnal time series | filter types

description: Species detection type. Targeted taxon detections include the detection approaches using qPCR, ddPCR and end point PCR, and multi taxon detection includes a metabarcoding HTS approach.
controlled_vocabulary_options: targeted taxon detection | multi taxon detection | other

description: A legal document giving official permission to do something with the resource.
A person or organization owning or managing rights over the resource.
example: The Regents of the University of California

description: Information about who can access the resource or an indication of its security status.
Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
example: location information not given for endangered species

description: Actions taken to make the shared data (i.e. location, date) less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request. Note this is not related to genetic generalisation within bioinforamtics workflows (i.e., OTU clustering).
example: Coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell.

description: A bibliographic reference for the resource.
A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence. i.e., links to a project website, submitted raw sequence data and environmental metadata.
The last date on which the database information was modified, following the format of yyyy-mm-dd
The version of the eDNA metadata checklist used to format the data
Link to public repository where raw sequence reads are archived. E.g., BioProject accession ID of NCBI SRA repository (at study level in study metadata)
Link to public repository where analysis code is archived

Sample Name is a name that you choose for the sample. It can have any format, but we suggest that you make it concise, unique and consistent within your lab, and as informative as possible. Every Sample Name from a single Submitter must be unique.

A type/category of a sample. 'Sample" includes biological and technical replicates. If negative or positive control was selected, provide further infomration under the terms fill neg_cont_type and pos_cont_type.
controlled_vocabulary_options: sample | negative control | positive control | PCR standard | other

description: The geographic latitude in decimal degrees using WGS84 datum. Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive. The desired minimum number of decimal places is the hundred-thousandth (0.00001) to achieve meter scale resolution.
requirement_level_condition: Mandatory unless specified under the term informationWithheld, or samp_category = negative control, positive control, or PCR standard

description: The geographic longitude in decimal degrees using WGS84 datum. Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive. The desired minimum number of decimal places is the hundred-thousandth (0.00001) to achieve meter scale resolution.
requirement_level_condition: Mandatory unless specified under the term informationWithheld, or samp_category = negative control, positive control, or PCR standard

description: The original latitude in any format (i.e. deg/min/sec, UTM) before converting to decimal degrees and WGS84. verbatimCoordinateSystem and verbatimGeodeticDatum should be stored as well.
The original longitude in any format (i.e. deg/min/sec, UTM) before converting to decimal degrees and WGS84. verbatimCoordinateSystem and verbatimGeodeticDatum should be stored as well.
The coordinate format of the verbatimLatitude and verbatimLongitude
controlled_vocabulary_options: decimal degrees | degrees minutes seconds | UTM | other

description: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which coordinates given in verbatimLatitude and verbatimLongitude, or verbatimCoordinates are based.
controlled_vocabulary_options: WGS84 | NAD84 | NAD27 | GDA94 | GDA2020 | ETRS89 | JGD2000 | other

description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by regions and localities. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC Geographic Location Name List INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html). Fixed format following <country or sea names>:<region>,<locality>. E.g., "USA: Maryland, Bethesda" , "Atlantic Ocean:Charlie Gibbs Fracture Zone"

The date and time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. Must follow ISO 8601 format (yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss). Time zone must be specified after the timestamp (e.g., "2008-01-23T19:23-06:00" in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, "2008-01-23T19:23Z" at UTC time). In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10Z; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant
The numeric value for the duration of the sampling event.
The units associated with the eventDurationValue
controlled_vocabulary_options: minutes | hours | days | months| years

description: Sample collection date before formatting
Sample collection time before formatting and time zone conversions
The end date of sample collection before formatting and time zone conversions if sampling was not an instance (single point in time)
The end time of sample collection before formatting and time zone conversions if sampling was not an instance (single point in time)

Major environmental system your sample came from. The systems identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done. Select from ENVO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. Examples include; estuarine biome [ENVO:01000020], tropical moist broadleaf forest biome [ENVO:01000228],
requirement_level_condition: Mandatory unless samp_category = negative control, positive control, or PCR standard
controlled_vocabulary_options: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428

description: The entity or entities which are in your sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample. Select from ENVO's layer class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_01000281. Examples include;  marine pelagic zone [ENVO:00000208], estuarine coastal surface layer [ENVO:01001302], shrub layer [ENVO:01000336]
requirement_level_condition: Mandatory unless samp_category = negative control, positive control, or qPCR standard
controlled_vocabulary_options: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_01000281

description: Environmental material or materials (pipe separated) immediately surrounded your sample prior to sampling. Select from ENVO's environmental material class (entity/ continuant/ independent continuant/ material entity/ environmental material): http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483. Examples include; soil [ENVO:00001998], marine sediment [ENVO:03000033], air [ENVO:00002005], sea water [ENVO:00002149], fresh water [ENVO:00002011], tap water [ENVO:00003096], fecal material [ENVO:00002003], digestive tract environment [ENVO:2100002], intestine environment [ENVO:2100002], planktonic material [ENVO:01000063]
requirement_level_condition: Mandatory unless samp_category = negative control, positive control, or qPCR standard
controlled_vocabulary_options: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483

description: Whether samples were taken from natural (0) or artificial (1) habitat. The examples of artificial habitat include mesocosm tank in lab, enclosure in zoo etc., including semi-natural systems. The definition of natural habitat is locations uncontrolled by researchers
The method employed for collecting the sample. Provide a link to a paper/ handbook/ standard operation protocol if any.

The device used to collect an environmental sample. This field accepts terms listed under environmental sampling device (https://ontobee.org/ontology/OBI?iri=http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0000968) such as syringe [OBI_0000422] and container [OBI_0000967] as well as free-text entry (i.e. niskin bottle, push core, spoon, water bottle).

Amount or size of original sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected from the environment. Specify the unit under the term samp_size_unit. Note: the amount or size of (sub)sample processed for DNA extraction should be entered under the term samp_vol_we_dna_ext.
Unit for samp_size
controlled_vocabulary_options: mL | L | mg | g | kg | cm2 | m2 | cm3 | m3 | other

description: Temperature at which the sample was stored. Enter either the fixed term "ambient temperature" or a numeric value. Note: If a sample was processed before DNA extraction (e.g., filtration, homogenisation, subsampling), enter the storage temperature before the process here, and the storage temperature of the processed sample (i.e., filter paper) under a term prepped_samp_store_temp.
controlled_vocabulary_options: numeric value | ambient temperature | other

description: Solution within which the sample was stored. Note: If a asample was processed before DNA extraction (e.g., filtration, homogenisation, subsampling), enter the storage solution before the process here, and the storage solution of the processed sample under the term prepped_samp_store_sol.
controlled_vocabulary_options: ethanol | sodium acetate | longmire | lysis buffer | none | other

description: Duration for which the sample was stored prior to DNA extraction, written in ISO 8601 format (i.e., P14D for 14 days period. P1Y6M for 1 year and 6 months period). Note: If a sample was processed before DNA extraction (e.g., filtration, homogenisation, subsampling), enter the storage duration before the process here, and the storage duration of the processed sample under the term prepped_samp_store_temp.
Additional information on sample storage method, that has not been shared in the given record.
example: The sample was thawed overnight at room temperature prior to DNA extraction

description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment (i.e. sieving, filtration, precipitation, homogenising, subsampling).
example: Water samples were pre-filtered using a sieve (200 micrometers), then filtered using a peristaltic pump (pore size 0.45 micrometers).

description: Whether water/ air samples were collected using active (i.e. pump, fan) or passive (i.e. submerged materials in water/air) filtration approach. Active = 1, Passive = 0

Duration of on-site filtration. In other words, filter deployment period. Recommended to record it if filters were deployed directly in the environment (i.e. airborne eDNA sampling, plankton tow, filters submerged in water). Follow the fixed format according to ISO 8601 durations (PnYnMnWnDTnHnMnS for P<date>T<time>). e.g., P1Y1M1DT1H1M1.1S = One year, one month, one day, one hour, one minute, one second, and 100 milliseconds
Refers to the mesh/pore size used to pre-filter/pre-sort the sample. Materials larger than the size threshold are excluded from the sample
Filtering pore size used in sample filtration
Diameter of a filter if circular
Surface area of a filter
Material of filter
controlled_vocabulary_options: cellulose | cellulose ester | glass fiber | thermoplastic membrane | track etched polycarbonate | nylon | other

description: Commercial names and brand of filter
Chemicals used in precipitation at the sample preparation step prior to DNA extraction
controlled_vocabulary_options: ethanol | isopropanol | sodium chloride | other

description: Force used for precipitation at the sample preparation step prior to DNA extraction
Time of centrifugation for precipitation at the sample preparation step prior to DNA extraction
Temperature during centrifugation for precipitation at the sample preparation step prior to DNA extraction
Temperature at which the prepared sample was stored prior to DNA extraction. Record either 'ambient' or a numeric value in degree Celsius.
controlled_vocabulary_options: numeric value | ambient temperature | other

description: Solution within which the prepared sample was stored prior to DNA extraction
controlled_vocabulary_options: ethanol | sodium acetate | longmire | lysis buffer | none | other

description: Duration for which the prepared sample was stored prior to DNA extraction
Additional information on sample preparation, storage and preservation prior to DNA extraction, that has not been shared in the given record
example: See Villacorta-Rath et al. (2020) (doi.org/10.1002/edn3.114) for the detailed precipitation protocols. ATL lysis buffer was used for prepped_samp_store_sol. Prepped_samp_store_temp was ambient, average of 22 degree Celsius

description: A negative control type used in an investigation. See Table 2 in Klymus et al. 2024 (DOI) for the description of each control type, how and why it's created. For example, process negative is a sample added during processing that lacks target DNA, such as blank filter papers.
controlled_vocabulary_options: site negative | field negative | process negative | extraction negative | PCR negative | other
example: field negative | process negative | extraction negative | PCR negative

description: A positive control type used in an investigation. See Table 2 in Klymus et al. 2024 (DOI) for the description of each control type, how and why it's created. For example, PCR positive is a introduced target material to monitor for PCR success, including moch community samples. Provide further details (e.g., synthetic DNA) where applicable.
(A list of) samp_id of the negative and positive controls realted to each sample
What were the protocols in the field and/or laboratory to minimise contaminations?
example: Sampling bottles were rinsed with 10% bleached and DI water. Single-use syringes and capsule filters were used for filtration. Single-use gloves were used to collect and filter each sample.

description: This field refers to the samp_name of the original (or parent) sample from which the current sample was derived. For example, if sample "S1" (the parent sample) was collected at a sampling site and later subsampled into three child samples with samp_names "S1_1", "S1_2", "S1_3", then "S1" is the value for sample_derived_from in each of the child samples. This includes the case of pcr technical replicates.

This field contains a list of samp_name values that represent the original samples combined to form the current sample. For example, if environmental samples "S1" and "S2" were pooled into a single sample "S3" at any stage (e.g., before or after DNA extraction), then the value for sample_composed_of in "S3" would be "S1 | S2".

This field lists the samp_name of biological replicates associated with the current sample. For example, if three biolgoical replicates ("S1_1", "S1_2", and "S1_3") were collected from the same sampling site, the value for biological_rep_relation in each of these replicates would be "S1_1 | S1_2 | S1_3".

Volume or mass of sample or subsamples that was processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected from the environment should be entered under the term samp_size. Specify the unit under the term samp_vol_ext_unit.
Unit for samp_vol_we_dna_ext
controlled_vocabulary_options: mL | L | mg | g | kg | cm2 | m2 | cm3 | m3 | other

description: The approach used to lyse DNA-containing material. For example, physical methods may involve freeze-thaw cycles or the uses of bead mills, homogenizers and sonicators. Thermal methods apply high temperatures, often used in combination wiht other methods.
controlled_vocabulary_options: physical | chemical | enzymatic | thermal | osmotic | other

description: The approach used to separate DNA from a mixture.
controlled_vocabulary_options: column-based | magnetic beads | centrifugation | precipitation | phenol chloroform | gel electrophoresis | other

description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample. If a custom extraction method has been developed and applied to the samples within this dataset, it is highly recommended to make the SOP available and provide the link here.
The name of the extraction kit used to recover the nucleic acid fraction of an input material
Description of modification made from a commercial or established protocol (nucl_acid_ext), if made.
example: Sample was lysed in 540 µL of ATL buffer and 60 µL of Proteinase K, and eluted in 100 µL of buffer EB, instead of 180 µL, 20 µL and 200 µL respectively

description: Was the extracted DNA cleaned/purified? Yes = 1, No =0
A description of DNA clean-up method. Provide the name of a commercial kit if used.
Concentration of total DNA after extraction
Description of method/instrument used for concentration measurement
Ratio of absorbance at 260 nm and 230 nm assessing DNA purity (mostly secondary measure, indicates mainly EDTA, carbohydrates, phenol), (DNA samples only).
The number of extracts that were pooled in to one sample before PCR
Additional information on nucleic acid extraction method, that has not been shared in the given record.
Was PCR performed in the study? Yes = 1, No (pcr-free approaches including shotgun metagenomics, Nanopore) = 0
The manufacturer and model of a thermocycler used
The total PCR reaction volume
A brief, concise identifier for sequencing library with no spaces or special characters, ensuring machine readability. This ID will be used in file names as 'library_id'.
How was the assay validated for specificify? e.g., in-silico, in-vitro, in-situ validations, sanger sequencing, repeat analysis with alternate assay, intra/inter species tests
Taxa or species name targeted by the primers, probes, and/or other approaches applied in the PCR.
modifications.made: Newly added, following the name style of targetTaxonomicScope

description: The taxonomic group(s) targeted in the study. This can differ from the targetTaxonomicPCR. For example, the targetTaxonomicPCR may be Chordata while the targetTaxonomicScope is Chondrichthyes (bony fish, sharks and rays).
Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies
controlled_vocabulary_options: 12S rRNA | 16S rRNA | 18S rRNA | 23S rRNA | 28S rRNA | rbcL | CytB | COI | COII | COIII | nifH | ITS | ND1 | ND2 | ND3 | ND4 | ND5 | ND6 | amoA | rpoB | rpoC1 | rpoC2 | matK | trnH | trnL | psbK | D-loop |  | other

description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA.
The length of the amplicon in basepairs EXCLUDING the primers, adaptors and MIDs. If it's a range, use pipe (i.e. 140 | 160)

Forward PCR primer (5' - 3') that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene. The primer sequence should NOT contain MIDs and adaptor sequences, and should be reported in uppercase letters. If multiple forward primers are present in a single PCR reaction, either report them separately in separate submissions (with separate OTU tables for each primer set), or list the primers here separated by pipe ( | ) and provide one OTU table resulting from all the primers applied here. The latter is recommended only when the multiple primers target the same gene region and thus a single OTU table was generated from the multiplexed PCR. This field is required except for PCR free methods.

Reverse PCR primer (5' - 3') that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene. The primer sequence should NOT contain MIDs and adaptor sequences, and should be reported in uppercase letters. If multiple reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction, either report them separately in separate submissions (with separate OTU tables for each primer set), or list the primers here separated by pipe ( | ) and provide one OTU table resulting from all the primers applied here. The latter is recommended only when the multiple primers target the same gene region and thus a single OTU table was generated from the multiplexed PCR. This field is required except for PCR free methods.
Name of the pcr_primer_forward. If multiple primers are listed in pcr_primer_forward, list the names respectively, separated by pipe ( | ).
Name of the pcr_primer_reverse. If multiple primers are listed in pcr_primer_reverse, list the names respectively, separated by pipe ( | ).
Reference (i.e. DOI) of the pcr_primer_forward. If multiple primers are listed in pcr_primer_forward, list the references respectively, separated by pipe ( | ).
Reference (i.e. DOI) of the pcr_primer_reverse. If multiple primers are listed in pcr_primer_reverse, list the references respectively, separated by pipe ( | ).
Volume of pcr_primer_forward per reaction
Volume of pcr_primer_reverse per reaction
Concentration of pcr_primer_forward
Concentration of pcr_primer_reverse

Type of fluorophore (reporter) used. Probe anneals within amplified target DNA. Polymerase activity degrades the probe that has annealed to the template, and the probe releases the fluorophore from it and breaks the proximity to the quencher, thus allowing fluorescence of the fluorophore.

Type of quencher used. The quencher molecule quenches the fluorescence emitted by the fluorophore when excited by the cycler’s light source As long as fluorophore and the quencher are in proximity, quenching inhibits any fluorescence signals.
controlled_vocabulary_options: Zero-End Quencher (ZEN) | TAMRA | lowa Black | Minor Groove Binder (MGB) | Black Hole Quencher (BHQ) | other

description: If applicable, probe sequence in the 5' to 3' direction
Reference (i.e. DOI) of the probe_seq
concentration of probe, if applicable
Name, brand, and manufacture of commercial, pre-made master mix
example: Luna® Universal qPCR Master Mix, New England Biolabs

description: composition of custom master mix, including the names, volumes and concentrations of additives (i.e., salts, buffers, enzyme and other components)
example: Each PCR reaction comprised: 1 x Taq Gold buffer (Applied Biosystems [ABI], USA), 2 nM MgCl2 (ABI, USA), 0.4 mg/mL BSA (Fisher Biotec, Australia), 0.25 mM dNTPs (Astral Scientific, Australia), 0.4 μM each of forward and reverse primers (Integrated DNA Technologies, Australia), 0.6 μL of 1/10,000 SYBR Green dye (Life Technologies, USA), 1 U of Taq polymerase Gold (ABI, USA), 2 μL of DNA, and made up to 25 μL with PCR grade water

description: Volume of DNA added in each PCR reaction
The number of PCR technical replicates. For metabarcoding, each replicate should employ an identical MID.
A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the nucleic acid amplification

Description of reaction conditions and components of PCR (including the second step in 2-step PCR if applicable). The recommended format is ´initial denaturation:degrees_minutes;annealing:degrees_minutes;elongation:degrees_minutes;final elongation:degrees_minutes;total cycles´, where possible.
The reaction temperature during the annealing phase of PCR.
Number of PCR cycles
The program used to analyse the PCR runs.
PCR plate ID
Additional information on PCR or PCR-free method, that has not been shared in the given record (i.e. multiplexing, hybridisation, CRISPR-Cas)
example: Blocking primer (TAGTATAGCTACGAAGCCGAGGAGG-c3) (Wilcox et al. 2014, DOI 10.1007/s12686-013-0113-4) was applied to prevent elongation of a closely related species

description: Amplicon visualisation method (i.e., qPCR, dPCR, gel electrophoresis, PCR capillary electrophoresis (PCR-CE), Loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP)) to determine the detection of a targeted taxon
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1
controlled_vocabulary_options: qPCR | dPCR | gel electrophoresis | CE-PCR | LAMP | other

description: Criteria to determine positive detection. For example, a certain number of positive amplifications per sample, sanger sequencing of amplicons
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1
example: The minimum number of PCR replicates of 2 with positive amplification

description: Method used for determining LOD e.g., DOI of a published procedure
The number of technical replicates that the LOD is applied to. See DOI: 10.1002/edn3.220
Assay's limit of detection (LOD) (the lowest amount of target taxon DNA that can be detected with a defined level of confidence).
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1

description: Unit for pcr_assay_lod
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1
controlled_vocabulary_options: copies/reaction | copies/µL | ng/reaction | ng/µL | other

description: Upper 95% confidence limit for LOD for a given number of technical replicates. See DOI: 10.1002/edn3.220
Lower 95% confidence limit for LOD for a given number of technical replicates. See DOI: 10.1002/edn3.220
Method used for determining LOQ e.g., DOI of a published procedure
The number of technical replicates that the LOQ is applied to. See DOI: 10.1002/edn3.220
Assay's limit of quantification (LOQ) (the lowest amount of target taxon DNA that can be quantitatively determined with a stated precision under the stated experimental conditions).
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1

description: unit for pcr_assay_loq
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1
controlled_vocabulary_options: copies/reaction | copies/µL | ng/reaction | ng/µL | other

description: Upper 95% confidence limit for LOQ for a given number of technical replicates. See DOI: 10.1002/edn3.220
Lower 95% confidence limit for LOQ for a given number of technical replicates. See DOI: 10.1002/edn3.220
The type of standard used for standard curves
controlled_vocabulary_options: synthetic double-stranded DNA | plasmid | amplicon | gDNA | other

description: The source of standard used for standard curves
DNA sequences of standard
Threshold for change in fluorescence signal between cycles
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & amp_vis_method = qPCR

description: The number of cycles when fluorescence signal from the target amplification is below background fluorescence not originated from the real target amplification.
Whether the threshold was set by the instrument (1) or manually (0).
Whether the baseline value was set by the instrument (1) or manually (0).
DNA concentration of qPCR standard
Unit for DNA concentration of qPCR standard
controlled_vocabulary_options: copies/reaction | copies/µL of DNA extract | copies/µL of reaction | ng/reaction | ng/µL of DNA extract | ng/µL of reaction | other

description: The number of cycles required for the fluorescent signal to cross a given value threshold above the baseline. Quantification cycle (Cq), threshold cycle (Ct), crossing point (Cp), and take-off point (TOP) refer to the same value from the real-time instrument. Use of quantification cycle (Cq), is preferable according to the RDML (Real-Time PCR Data Markup Language) data standard (http://www.rdml.org).
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & amp_vis_method = qPCR

description: Relative Fluorescence Units (RFU)
qPCR amplification efficiency calculated from slope
R-squared value of a qPCR standard curve. This shall be specific to each pcr_plate_id.
Slope of a qPCR standard curve. This shall be specific to each pcr_plate_id.
Intercept of a qPCR standard curve. This shall be specific to each pcr_plate_id.
Method to output estimatedNumberOfCopies
controlled_vocabulary_options: Ct/Cq with standard curve | Ct/Cq with standard bionomial data | direct output from the PCR instrument used | gel fluorescence intensities | other
example: Ct/Cq with standard curve | Ct/Cq with standard bionomial data

description: Estimated concentration of target molecules. Describe the approach taken to estimate it under the term estaimtedNumberOfCopies_method.
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1

description: Unit for estimatedNumberOfCopies
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1
controlled_vocabulary_options: copies/reaction | copies/µL of DNA extract | copies/µL of reaction | ng/reaction | ng/µL of DNA extract | ng/µL of reaction | other

description: The targeted taxon was detected (1) or not detecte (0), based on the detection criteria
requirement_level_condition: If detection_type = targeted taxon detection & pcr_0_1 = 1, for biological replicate

description: PCR approach for metabarcoding
controlled_vocabulary_options: one-step PCR | two-step PCR | ligation-based | other

description: A brief, concise identifier for sequencing library with no spaces or special characters, ensuring machine readability. This ID will be used in file names as 'library_id'.
General sequencing platform used.
controlled_vocabulary_options: ILLUMINA | BGISEQ | CAPILLARY | DNBSEQ | ELEMENT | GENAPSYS | GENEMIND | HELICOS | ION_TORRENT | LS454 | OXFORD_NANOPORE | PACBIO_SMRT | TAPESTRI | VELA_DIAGNOSTICS | ULTIMA | other

description: Sequencing instrument (manufacturer and model) used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (https://ontobee.org/ontology/OBI?iri=http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0002750)
The name of sequencing kit
Specify whether to expect single, paired, or other configuration of reads
controlled_vocabulary_options: paired end | single end | other

description: The location the sequencing run was performed. Indicate the name of the lab or core facility where samples were sequenced
example: University of Maryland Genomics Resource Center

description: Forward sequencing adapter. The sequence should be reported in uppercase letters
Reverse sequencing adapter. The sequence should be reported in uppercase letters
Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating libraries
example: The library was size selected using a Pippin-Prep (Sage Science, Beverly, USA), purified using the Qiaquick PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen), quantified using a Qubit (Invitrogen) and diluted to 2 nM before loading it onto a MiSeq Flow Cell

description: Forward multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that was used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters
Reverse multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that was used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters
A file name of raw sequencing data. If paired end, fill filename2 for the reverse read
A raw sequencing data file name of reverse reads if lib_layout = paired end
Additional information on library preparation and sequencing method, that has not been shared in the given record.
Standard operating procedures, references, link to scripts, that were used in quality filtering, assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences

Parameters used to filter chimera sequences if note default
Software and the version used for OTU/ASV clustering
The percentage similarity threshold used for OTU/ASV clustering. For ASV clustering, the cutoff is typically 100% similarity.

minimum read counts thresholds. e.g., 10 reads, 5% relative read abundance, noise (e.g., (relative) read counts) detected in blanks. Answer either numeric value with the unit specified under the terms min_reads_cutoff_unit, "noise detecte in blanks", or "other:FREE TEXT DESCRIPTION".
controlled_vocabulary_options: numeric value | noise detected in blanks | other

description: Unit of the min_reads_cutoff. i.e. reads, % relative read abundance
controlled_vocabulary_options: reads | % | other

description: Software and the version to remove reads below minimum read threshold

List of reference database(s) (i.e. sequences not generated as part of the current study) along with version number, that were used to assign taxonomy to OTUs or ASVs. If custome database was used, enter 'custom' here, and provide the information of the database under the term otu_db_custom
Description of custom reference database(s) (i.e. coverage of taxa, region) if applied to assign taxonomy to OTUs or ASVs
example: Unpublished custom database, containing COI sequences of 209 fish species collected from Western Australia (study area)

description: High level cetegory of taxonomic assignment approach. A sequence similarity approach include BLAST, MEGAN, custom R function to group sequences with 100% identify. A sequence composition approach includes naive bayes classifier, Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) classification, Tourmaline, QIMME feature-classifier. Examples of phylogeny and probabilistic approaches are SEPP and PROTAX, respectively.
controlled_vocabulary_options: sequence similarity | sequence composition | phylogeny | probabilistic | other

description: Alignment tool/software used for taxonomic assignment
Minimum percent identity for taxonomic assignment
Minimum percent query coverage for taxonomic assignment
How was the taxa collapsed to higher taxonomic levels? i.e. lowest common ancestor
example: Taxonomic levels were dropped to the lowest common ancestor (LCA) with the similarity thresholds of 99%, and also based on % identify thresholds (>98% species, 95-98% genus, 90-95% family).

description: Additional information on parameters and cutoffs used for taxonomic assignment, that have not been shared in the given record.
How were contaminations screened and applied in data curation/analyses/interpretation?
example: Taxa detected in negative controls were checked, and the read counts were applied as a cutoff to call presence.

description: How were species distribution information screened and applied?
example: Distribution information was checked using FishBase, and species that did not reside in the study area were removed.

description: How were non-target species screened and applied?
example: Non-targeted species (i.e. domestic animals, humans and non-marine species) were removed from the curated OTU table and downstream data analyses. OTUs that were assigned to species in WoRMS were kept in the curated OTU table.

description: Description of other screening criteria and approaches
Additional information on bioinformatics, that has not been shared in the given record.
example: The min_reads_cutoff was 1 read, but singletons were kept if the same sequence was detected in multiple samples. Data was curated using r-package LULU, minimum_mismatch cutoff 90%

description: The total number of raw sequence reads for each sample
The number of filtered sequence reads for each sample, that made it through bioinforamtic filtering and used for final/subsequent analyses
Total numbe of OTUs or ASVs for each sample
Total number of OTUs or ASVs assgined to taxa based on the study-specific thresholds for each sample
Query sequence ID. Must be unique within the dataset
The DNA sequence
The full scientific name of the kingdom
The full scientific name of the phylum or division
The full scientific name of the class
The full scientific name of the order
The full scientific name of the family
The full scientific name of the genus
The name of the first or species epithet of the scientificName.
The full scientific name of the genus and species
The authorship information for the scientificName
The taxonomic rank of the most specific name in the scientificName
controlled_vocabulary_options: kingdom | phylum | class | order | family | genus | species | other

description: An identifier for the assigned taxon (or taxa in the case of mutliple hits). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
The taxonomy database correspoingind to taxonID.
A string representing the taxonomic identification as it appeared in the original record (i.e. the database used such as NCBI)
example: Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Actinopterygii; Perciformes; Lutjanidae; Lutjanus; Lutjanus_erythropterus

description: Accession ID of the best matching sequence from a reference database
Reference database (i.e. sequences not generated as part of the current study) of the best matching sequence (accesssion_id)
The percentage of sequence identity between a query sequence obtained from eDNA and a reference sequence in a database.
The percentage coverage of the query sequence that aligns with a reference sequence in a database.
Confidence score for the taxonomic assignment, such as from bootstrapping
The weather on the sampling day

The lesser depth of a range of depth (vertical distance below the local surface) at which a sample was collected. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. If there is only one single point of depth (no range), the values in minimumDepthInMeters and maximumDepthInMeters are the same.

The greater depth of a range of depth (vertical distance below the local surface) at which a sample was collected. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. If there is only one single point of depth (no range), the values in minimumDepthInMeters and maximumDepthInMeters are the same.

Measurement of total depth of water column. For example, if a sea surface water sample was collected at a sampling site where the water depth was 15m, enter 15 here and 0 under the terms minimumDepthInMeters and maximumDepthInMeters.

Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit. i.e. 0m for seawater sample

Heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds. It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth's surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air
Temperature of the sample at the time of sampling
Concentration of chlorophyll
Measurement of light intensity
Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here. Expected_value: parameter name;measurement value
example: Bicarbonate ion concentration;2075 micromole per kilogram

description: Ph measurement of the sample, or liquid portion of sample, or aqueous phase of the fluid
Reference or method used in determining pH

The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater
Concentration of suspended particulate matter
Stage of tide
Measure of the amount of cloudiness or haziness in water caused by individual particles
Measurement of magnitude and direction of flow within a fluid
Amount of water vapour in the air, at the time of sampling relative to the maximum amount of water vapor the air can hold at a given temperature and pressure. Also known as relative humidity.
Description and/or the amount of solar energy that arrives at a specific area of a surface at the time of sampling. i.e. fully exposed, partially shaded,cloud cover 20%, 1.36kW/m2/day
Wind direction (the direction from which a wind originates) at the time of sampling
Speed of wind measured at the time of sampling
The scientific name of host species. i.e. predator species where a gut content sample was dissected from
Description of life stage of host. Select from UBERON's life cycle class (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/UBERON_0000104)
controlled_vocabulary_options: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/UBERON_0000104

description: Total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host.
The unit of host_tot_mass
controlled_vocabulary_options: mg | g | kg | other

description: The height of subject
The unit of host_height
controlled_vocabulary_options: mm | cm | m | other

description: The length of subject
The unit of host_length_unit
controlled_vocabulary_options: mm | cm | m | other

description: Dissolved inorganic carbon concentration in the sample, typically measured after filtering the sample using a 0.45 micrometre filter
Concentration of dissolved inorganic nitrogen
Concentration of dissolved organic carbon in the sample, liquid portion of the sample, or aqueous phase of the fluid
Dissolved organic nitrogen concentration measured as; total dissolved nitrogen - NH4 - NO3 - NO2
Concentration of dissolved oxygen
Total dissolved nitrogen concentration, reported as nitrogen, measured by: total dissolved nitrogen = NH4 + NO3NO2 + dissolved organic nitrogen
Total inorganic nitrogen content
Total nitrogen concentration of water samples, calculated by: total nitrogen = total dissolved nitrogen + particulate nitrogen. Can also be measured without filtering, reported as nitrogen
Total particulate carbon content
Total organic carbon content
Reference or method used in determining total organic carbon
Total nitrogen content of the sample
Reference or method used in determining the total nitrogen
Total carbon content
Concentration of particulate organic carbon
Concentration of particulate organic nitrogen
Concentration of nitrate in the sample
Concentration of nitrite in the sample
Concentration of nitrogen (total)
Concentration of organic carbon
Concentration of organic matter
Concentration of organic nitrogen
